reviewText:
One of many Pajama Sam games I never played as a child.

This was lacking a few things: same bgm alternations throughout the game--pretty lack-a-daisy, the voice casting for lightning was a bit disappointing than what I imagined, game didn't feel that all engaging overall unlike the first one. Title was a bit misleading along with the prologue, thought it was to go against Thunder and LIghtning, like going after Darkness in the first game, not help them... then again...

Still, that's just minor things, and I'm being a bit nit-picky.

Still a good game for kids; they may not get much of the jokes or references right off the bat. Learn a few things about weather and how it works, along with a bit of economics... although that's very boring stuff so leave that to the carrot and the board of directors to discuss amongst themselves.

reviewText:
An Instant Childhood Point-and-Click Classic from the Days of my Childhood, which consist of the old MS-DOS, Windows 3.1, Windows 95, Windows 98 & Windows 98SE PCs in which you help Pajama Sam repair the Weather Machine at World Wide Weather by collecting all 4 of the missing parts for the Snow, Wind, Rain & Sun Machines (Automated Snowflake Inspector or ASI, Wignut, Y-Pipe & Velo Velocimomometer).

[Previously on Pajama Man]
Captain Gelatin: Hold it right there, Earthquaker! Stop that evil doing!

Earthquaker (he is dressed like a Quaker): Your low-calorie threats mean nothing to me!

Earthquaker stomps on the ground, causing a fracture, which
approaches Captain Gelatin.

Earthquaker: Take that Captain Gelatin!

The fracture reaches Captain Gelatin and his superhero friends (Milk Man and a giant sandwich) and then stops. The superheros stare at the fracture and then stare at each other. A small earthquake occurs, easily defeating the three superheros.

Gelatin Man: C-c-can't stop sha-a-king...

Dust Devil: Ha! You and your lunchboxes are no match for the foul weather men! Now we shall take the cosmic eraser and with it we shall control the world!

Mysterious Heroic Voice: Not so fast, Dust Devil!

Pajama Man bursts out of the cosmic eraser box.

Dust Devil: Pajama Man! I'll spin you to the far corners of the earth, do-gooder!

Pajama Man: My handy dandy Pajama Man superpowered vac says different!

Dust Devil: Pajama man! You sa... (his dialogue is cut off by the sound of the vacuum).

Pajama Man: Exactly!

reviewText:
If you would dare to look at Pajama Sam 2 and say to yourself, 'Well, it's a sequel, it can't be quite as good,' you need to immediately rethink all of your life decisions and then play Pajama Sam 2. While there are some slight changes here and there to keep the game feeling fresh, Pajama Sam 2 is packed with all the distinct features that made the first game so amazing: more pointing and clicking, more item collecting and more existential journeys of self-discovery. Instead of collecting socks, Sam collects a large variety of puzzle pieces, which is likely symbolic of the courage and morality he must piece together in order to confront his crippling fear of thunder and lightning. Speaking of puzzles, Pajama Sam 2 is like a puzzle with every piece in its proper place: with its moving story, well-crafted characters and exciting gameplay, this game feels incredibly polished and complete. Throughout its development, the geniuses at Humongous Entertainment must have known they had a masterpiece on their hands.

If I had to give this game a score, I would give it a 10/10 with a complimentary smiley face.

reviewText:
As I've looked through a lot of the Humongous library on Steam, I've also seen a lot of fans who grew up with the games (including myself) giving high reviews to this game. Like 10/10's and what not. To be frank, I like these games as well. But are they absolute perfect? Hell, no. Not by my standards at least. The best Humongous game was probably Pajama Sam 1, and I'd probably give that a 7/10 or 8/10. But what about Pajama Sam 2? Ah yes, dear reader. What ABOUT Pajama Sam 2?

The game does have a lot of color and charm. It looks nice , and there are plenty of nice jokes only adults would get, as usual. However, the biggest dip in the game would be the story. In the original Pajama Sam, the story had just enough control in the player's hands to make the story build to an ultimate climax no matter how they got their objects. In Pajama Sam 2, the same thing is present, but out of nowhere, after you put in the third missing piece, a new story element pops out of nowhere in the appearance of a new character that is there purely for the reason of building tension. What was interesting about the tension in Pajama Sam 1, is it was shown through the visuals and the build-up both inside and outside of the story. Everything was connected, but detached enough for you to have your own adventure.

And I think the biggest reason that the story just isn't that good is because of the set-up. Pajama Sam 1 had the point of the story be that you don't need to be afraid of the dark. Simple but still good. And the story built up to that overall point being the main message. In Pajama Sam 2, Sam instantly finds out, Hey! My fears are just controlled by a couple ladies in a sky-factory! There's nothing to be afraid of!"

reviewText: A very cool point-and-click adventure game with an imaginative setting and beautiful backgrounds. Puzzles are easy, meaning it's a great introduction to the genre. It was one of my favorites growing up, and I am happy to report it's still fun and funny. In addition to the point-and-click gameplay, each background is full of stuff to click on. It's like a pop-up book, which for some reason totally captivates me.

reviewText: Pajama Sam 2 is a young superhero's quest to fix all the weather machines he inadvertently disrupted on his way to the top.\nI played this game numerous times when I was a kid. And now thanks to Night Dive, I can play it forever. Not too long ago I bought all the Humongous games on sale for $25, so now whenever a new old HE! game comes out on Steam, I get those too. And since most of these games are compatable and bundled with ScummVM, I can play them with high-res pixel filters that make the games look better than ever, especially on HD monitors. If you were a child of the 90's like me, you'll have played this game, and if you didn't, now's as good a time as ever. 10/10

reviewText: This is the first Pajama Sam game I played without the nostalgia glasses, since I only ever played the first as a child.\n\nLike the first one, you have a wide assortment of things to click on, put together, characters to talk to, etc.  Like a lot of the games from this developrer, it is good for helping a child work on their problem solving skills in a safe and entertaining format.  Your child won't necessarily learn too much about the weather from the game, but it can be a good springboard for starting discussions about the weather, what it's for and why it is what it is.

reviewText:
Pajama Sam 2: Thunder and Lightning Aren't So Frightening truly is a work of art. I don't mean that lightly. The way it's animated plus its music gives it that title in my book. I can find myself exploring one room for an hour, maybe even hours at a time. The frustration of not finding the solution is filled with relaxation and calmness because of the ambient music. The way the worlds are crafted is truly mindblowing. They had a system in which you had to perfect a puzzle to earn a new area, and you would use that new area to earn more puzzles. In layman's terms, to earn more rooms, you had to perfect current puzzles. They ditched that and added the ability to google the solutions. I'm very glad they added this system and was skeptical about buying it. But now that I did buy it, I do not regret it even for a second. One thing I really love about this game is how you don't have to unlock the first room. In a sense, this game is open world. That sense is that many rooms are available to you, and you can choose whether you want to advance into more challenging rooms, or stay where you're at. To get an S in completion, you have to play ever variation.

Another thing I absolutely enjoy about Pajama Sam 2: Thunder and Lightning Aren't So Frightening is its expasive community. There are lots of flash games for you to sharpen your skills on, and lots of people who can set a good example. I'm sure most of the people who get best times on all the levels have a Youtube channel, so you can probably catch them there. The community may or not be active, but it sure is good and friendly.

Overall, in terms of gameplay, music, artstyle, animation, and difficulty (it's not an easy game, but it's not that hard of a game either. It just depends on how much you want to play it), I rate this game:

10/10
BUY THIS GAME.
